title: This technology could alter the entire planet. These groups want every nation to have a say.

last_post.content:
Not a fan of MIT Tech Review *at all*, but this is one of the first times I've seen a ~journalist — as opposed to a novelist like Kim Stanley Robinson —explicitly address *the* fundamental problem with geoengineering: "planetary averages say little about the complex, contradictory, overlapping, and sometimes unpredictable ways in which regional climate conditions interact with ecosystems, economies, infrastructure, emergency response systems, and more."

The essence of ~environmental thinking is the recognition that the earth is, for many purposes, a closed system. *Any* significant local change will necessarily have global effects, where 'global' is basically hand-waving, a proxy for refractory derivative consequences.

Whenever I hear some pie-in-the-sky proposal for gigantic contraptions that'll 'scrub' or 'sink' enough carbon to make a difference, I'm like 🤔 *ah, so you mean there will be massive new wind systems, right?* 🤔 Which means radically different conditions for humidity, dust and soil, birds, particulates (including seeds, pollen, pathogens, etc), and so on.

That's not to say 'we' shouldn't try these things; but it *is* to say that experiments on that scale will demand a regime capable of holding people / orgs / govs accountable for the consequences of their actions. (Close parallels with current debates about AI, yes?) And our current model of governmentality — a lunatic, inherited patchwork of things called nations and regional alliances — isn't up to that task at all.

https://www.technologyreview.com/2023/04/17/1071654/this-technology-could-alter-the-entire-planet-these-groups-want-every-nation-to-have-a-say/

Wow 😲

Just discovered a decentralized and federated social network that works through the Gemini protocol.

It's called @sequel, and you can access it here:

gemini://sequel.space

Right now, it operates on 2 nodes with 95 users.

To say I'm shocked is an understatement.

If you're unaware of the Gemini protocol, it's something that resembles HTTP and Gopher. Here's info:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gemini_(protocol)

If you want to read about @sequel on the regular web, here it is:

https://sequel.space/home/

title: Seeing Like a Toolkit: How Toolkits Envision the Work of AI Ethics | Proceedings of the ACM on Human-Computer Interaction

last_post.content:
Sharing a new (open access!) #CSCW paper co-authored with Michael Madaio & Nick Merrill:

"Seeing Like a Toolkit: How Toolkits Envision the Work of AI Ethics" https://dl.acm.org/doi/10.1145/3579621

We analyze a set of AI ethics toolkits to understand how they imagine the *work* of doing ethics. (Who's doing it? When and how? How should a worker justify doing ethics work?). Broadly there's a lack of guidance about org & institutional power dynamics.

(I'll be at #CHI2023 if you want to chat more!)

title: Google’s AI dilemma: Move fast or ‘don’t be evil’

last_post.content:
For years Google has been dominant in both AI and search. Now it's threatened in both—and so are its professed values.

I wrote about how AI chatbots could disrupt Google search--not by being better, per se, but by generating just enough interest and hype to force it to respond, potentially in ways that degrade its own core product. https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2023/04/19/google-bard-pichai-60-minutes-ai/

I'm recruiting postdocs for two research projects on studying cross-cultural norms and on modeling linguistic style https://forms.gle/WuiJmuWp7Qih5onZ8. Applicants from non-CS areas (e.g., Linguistics/Psychology) are also encouraged to apply.
